ar.com.hjg.pngj

Class IDatChunkWriter

  • java.lang.Object
    • ar.com.hjg.pngj.IDatChunkWriter

  • public class IDatChunkWriter
extends Object
    Outputs a sequence of IDAT-like chunk, that is filled progressively until the max chunk length is reached (or until flush())

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      IDatChunkWriter(OutputStream outputStream) 
      IDatChunkWriter(OutputStream outputStream, byte[] b) 
      IDatChunkWriter(OutputStream outputStream, int maxChunkLength)

      Modifier and Type Method and Description

      void flush()
      Writes a chhunk if there is more than minLenToWrite.
      int getAvailLen() 
      byte[] getBuf()
      You can write directly to this buffer, using getOffset() and getAvailLen().

      int getChunksWriten() 
      int getOffset() 
      long getTotalBytesWriten() 
      void incrementOffset(int n)
      triggers an flush+reset if appropiate
      protected int minLenToWrite() 
      protected void postReset()
      this will be called after reset
      void write(byte[] b, int o, int len)
      this should rarely be used, the normal way (to avoid double copying) is to get the buffer and write directly to it

    • Method Detail

      • getChunkId

        protected byte[] getChunkId()

      • flush

        public final void flush()
        Writes a chhunk if there is more than minLenToWrite. This is normally called internally, but can be called explicitly to force flush.

      • getOffset

        public int getOffset()

      • getAvailLen

        public int getAvailLen()

      • incrementOffset

        public void incrementOffset(int n)
        triggers an flush+reset if appropiate

      • write

        public void write(byte[] b,
         int o,
         int len)
        this should rarely be used, the normal way (to avoid double copying) is to get the buffer and write directly to it

      • postReset

        protected void postReset()
        this will be called after reset

      • minLenToWrite

        protected int minLenToWrite()

      • close

        public void close()

      • getBuf

        public byte[] getBuf()
        You can write directly to this buffer, using getOffset() and getAvailLen(). You should call incrementOffset(int) inmediately after.

      • getTotalBytesWriten

        public long getTotalBytesWriten()
